entry.title: It always takes more time
entry.content:
It always takes more time
‚Ä¶to lose weight
‚Ä¶to gain weight
‚Ä¶to build good habits
‚Ä¶to get rid of bad habits
‚Ä¶to arrive on time
‚Ä¶to finish the project on time
‚Ä¶to reach your goal
‚Ä¶for your project to start making money

But that is OK. All we have to do is push forward. Every day. Giving our all. And, of course, account that everything will take longer than we want it. Most of the time.

Two months ago, I started building a ‚Äúsimple‚Äù job board - 99remotejobs.com. I thought it would take me a week. It took me a month!

This short post was supposed to take me only 15 minutes, of couse, yet it took me 40.

When I started SaaSHub I though AND CALCULATED that if the project had 10,000 visitors a day, I would be all set - making enough passive income to have a comfortable life. That was naive. It will take much more. For example, the project has about 8,000 visitors a day today (80% of my initial target), and it is making only 15% of my target. But that is OK. I keep pushing forward - every Day.

entry.title: Marcus Aurelius on Pragmatism
entry.content:
I‚Äôve been reading ‚ÄúThe Daily Stoic‚Äù for the last 2 years. Almost every day. To me, that‚Äôs one of the best ways to jump-start my days, and it takes only a few minutes. I can easily say that it‚Äôs become a habit already.

Here they are three of my highlighted quotes by Marcus Aurelius on Pragmatism.

Start with where the world is

Do now what nature demands of you. Get right to it if that‚Äôs in your power. Don‚Äôt look around to see if people will know about it. Don‚Äôt await the perfection of Plato‚Äôs Republic, but be satisfied with even the smallest step forward.

Anything can be an advantage

Just as nature of rational things has given to each person their rational powers, so it also gives us this power - just as nature turns to its own purpose any obstacle or any opposition, so any rational person can convert any obstacle into the raw material for their own purpose.

Don‚Äôt sweat the small stuff

It is essential for you to remember that the attention you give to any action should be in due proportion to its worth, for then you won‚Äôt tire and give up, if you aren‚Äôt busying yourself with lesser things beyond what should be allowed.

Apart from being exceptionally wise and one of the most quoted stoics, Marcus Aurelius was amongst the longest-reigning Roman emperors (19 years). As a perspective, many emperors lasted between a few months and a few years.

entry.title: Why I don‚Äôt do affiliate marketing on SaaSHub

link.title: Why I don‚Äôt do affiliate marketing on SaaSHub

entry.content:
During the last year, I‚Äôve been approached on a regular basis with requests to take part in various affiliate and referral programs. To be honest, some of them seemed decent and applicable to SaaSHub. For example, a VPN service. If we take the ‚ÄúBest VPN Software‚Äù page, it is quite suitable for including an affiliate link to a relevant VPN service. SaaSHub could drive a few sales, and I could make some additional money. Perfect. Well, it is a bit more complicated than that, at least to me.

First, yes, I may make a hundred dollars through a particular affiliate program; however, each product will require separate management, accounting and collecting the money through a different channel. The overhead and admin will be more than I can afford in regards to time and energy. It is just not viable at this stage.

Second, I will always be trying to be as objective as possible with the product lists on SaaSHub. However, if there were affiliate links and the relevant disclosures, many people will start questioning how genuine the ordering of the products is. In essence, the cost of using affiliate links would be losing some trust even if you are trustworthy.

My ‚Äúworkaround‚Äù is offering a self-service and very affordable product promo. It is that easy. As long as a product has been approved on SaaSHub, it can be promoted for $99/month. That subscription fee is nothing for the marketing budges of most SaaS products, and they can easily test whether it works for them. At the end of the month, there are no additional admin costs and I get one single payment from one source instead of 50 payments from 50 distinct sources arriving in 28 different days (if I were using affiliates).

In the end, I don‚Äôt think that affiliate and referral programs are bad or dishonest. If one discloses them and doesn‚Äôt promote ‚Äúfake‚Äù products, they could possibly be a viable revenue stream. They just don‚Äôt work for SaaShub and me and now.

entry.title: Running and Reading - the key to life

link.title: Running and Reading - the key to life

entry.content:
This has always been one of my favourite Will Smith‚Äôs speeches. It‚Äôs short and powerful. If you haven‚Äôt listened to it, please do. Now.

I will transcribe it here, so it stays written down for posterity.
Here it is - Will Smith‚Äôs wisdom:

The key to life is running and reading!

Why running? When you are running, there is a little person that talks to you, and that little person says ‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôm tired, my lungs are going to pop, I‚Äôm so hurt, I‚Äôm so tired, there‚Äôs no way I could possibly continue.‚Äù. And YOU want to quit. That person, if you learn how to defeat that person when you are running, you will learn how to not quit when things get hard in your life.

Why reading? The reason that reading is so important - there‚Äôve been millions and billions and gazillions of people that have lived before all of us. There‚Äôs no new problem you could have - with your parents, with school‚Ä¶ with anything. There‚Äôs no new problem that someone hasn‚Äôt already solved and wrote about it in a book.

OK, as a person working in tech, I know that there are problems that are new and people haven‚Äôt written about them. Yet, ‚Äúreading‚Äù helps us solve unsolved problems.

BONUS: Running makes you fit and happier. It makes you more productive in general.
BONUS2: For more motivation about running, I‚Äôd recommend listening/reading ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt hurt me‚Äù by David Goggins.

entry.title: On always looking for opportunities
entry.content:
There are great opportunities - all the time. We just have to be actively looking for them. And we should be prepared to be able to catch the moment when it comes.

I went to a local Sushi place recently. Nothing exciting, however, instead of writing down my name and contacts on a piece of paper, I was asked to simply scan a barcode and fill in a very simple and unobtrusive form. Easy. Here in Australia, restaurants are required to keep a record of the who and when visited their spot so that if a COVID-19 case shows up, they can do a more effective contact tracking. OK, a few days later, I went to a different restaurant and was asked to scan a barcode again and enter my details. They were using the same service as my details were prefilled. All I had to do was click a big centred green button. How convenient.

On the way home, I was thinking about how this service was built specifically to cater to the needs around COVID. It was very simple and ALL restaurants around Australia and New Zealand, have to comply with this new requirement. I checked the website of the service, a SaaS product, its entry price was $19 per month, and they stated that 60,000 businesses around Aus and NZ were using them! That‚Äôd be around $120,000 per month for a simple check-in app. Of course, you will have to spend some money on marketing and effort on your go-to-market strategy, yet it‚Äôs a perfect example of catching the moment.

I, and I imagine many other makers, can easily build such a simple service in a month. Even better, a team of a technical and a sales person could bootstrap such a business quite easily should they see the opportunity and execute quickly enough. Yes, this requirement won‚Äôt last forever; however, I‚Äôm sure that many founders wouldn‚Äôt mind making a million dollars in a year.

I believe that similar opportunities show up all the time. All it takes is being prepared so that you can execute quickly enough when you notice them.
entry.summary: There are great opportunities - all the time. We just have to be actively looking for them. And we should be prepared to be able to catch the moment when it comes.

entry.title: The 3 Day Domain Name Rule
entry.content:
I will share one of my little ‚Äúsecrets‚Äù that have saved me hundreds or thousands of dollars - ‚ÄúThe 3 Day Domain Name Rule‚Äù.

The Rule

Whenever you have an idea of a great domain name, wait for 3 days, at least, before buying it.

It‚Äôs that simple. However, be warned, there might be an uneasy feeling that someone is going to grab the domain before you. It will be haunting you on the back of your mind. You have to resist it and stick to the rule. Both your future self and your money will thank you.

Also, you could be thinking ‚ÄúBut, it‚Äôs only $8.95‚Äù. Yet, it‚Äôs more. Usually, a few times more. Let me tell you why. We, people, hate losing things that we own. Hence, once you own the domain and have put your credit card in, it is very very likely you will be paying for that name for a few years. Domain registrars are aware of that, too. That‚Äôs why the registration price, on many platforms, is %30 - %50 less compared to the following up renewals.

Here it is an example with GoDaddy: Reg $12; Renewal: $18 (+50%).

I‚Äôd say that you will keep your shiny new domain, on average, for 3 years at least.
That makes ~$50!, and NOT $11.99.

.io domains are the worst. First, they are heaps more expensive - $54 to reg it and $60 to renew => a $174 idea ownership cost. What is more, they seem short, trendy, and many of them are not registered yet. If you are building a tech product, you will be lured into buying one of those. Do yourself a favour and either try coming up with a .com name or at least apply the rule and don‚Äôt rush.

Now, back to the rule. At some point, after buying many domains and losing some money, I realised that my enthusiasm for the ‚Äúgreat‚Äù idea I had the day before would start disappering more often than not. Only the ‚Äúgood‚Äù ideas stuck for longer than a few days. Then, I came with this rule of thumb for myself - never buy a domain name without waiting for at least 3 days after coming up with the idea of it. I‚Äôve never had a single case when someone else would grab the domain before me. NEVER. The closest one was about 3 months afer I had the idea. The domain name was vivanotes.com if you are curious. To be honest, it felt a bit bad, as I still had the idea written down in my notes. Yet, I will most probably never build that project and have saved hundreds or thousands of dollars along the way.

Why 3 days? There is no scientific reason! It‚Äôs easy to remember, it‚Äôs longer than a weekend and it works for me.
entry.summary: I will share one of my little ‚Äúsecrets‚Äù that have saved me hundreds or thousands of dollars - ‚ÄúThe 3 Day Domain Name Rule‚Äù.

entry.title: ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù questions and why to avoid them

link.title: ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù questions and why to avoid them

entry.content:
Don‚Äôt ask questions that start with ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù unless you want your counterpart to defend a goal that serves you. ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù is always an accusation, in any language.

The advice of avoiding ‚Äúwhy questions‚Äù is from the book ‚ÄúNever Split The Difference‚Äù by Chris Voss. If we think about it, how straight to the point is that? When was the last time someone asked you ‚ÄúWhy this‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhy that‚Äù and you weren‚Äôt left with a bit of sour feeling. For example, many bosses would use ‚Äúwhy questions‚Äù in meetings after something had gone wrong (‚ÄúWhy did you do that‚Äù, ‚ÄúWhy didn‚Äôt we sell enough‚Äù, ‚ÄúWhy couldn‚Äôt we release on time‚Äù, etc.). However, that might be counterproductive in many cases.

The better alternative is asking calibrated and open-ended questions that direct the other person towards solving your problem. Such could be ‚ÄúHow‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhat‚Äù - ‚ÄúHow can we solve this problem?‚Äù, ‚ÄúWhat can we do to improve the process?‚Äù, etc. Coming up with these non-why questions will lead to better results for both parties in most cases. Moreover, they may start flowing naturally to you once you remember to avoid ‚Äúwhy questions‚Äù in negotiations as a rule of thumb.
entry.summary: Don‚Äôt ask questions that start with ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù unless you want your counterpart to defend a goal that serves you. ‚ÄúWhy‚Äù is always an accusation, in any language.

entry.title: Hello world
entry.content:
I have decided to start blogging again. I used to blog relatively regularly about 10 years ago. More or less, when I was actively developing svejo.net. Then I stopped. Blogging requires consistency, time, dedication and even more. However, you reap the benefits much later. I guess that‚Äôs the reason why many people stop blogging (apart from moving to walled gardens like Medium, Twitter, LinkedIn, FB, etc.).

Yet, I‚Äôve been observing a slight renaissance in blogging in the last year or two. That and the idea that one improves his thinking by writing, made me wanna start blogging again.

I have also had the idea of building an RSS reader. It has been boiling at the back of my head for almost a year. I even bought a domain a few months ago. I have the mantra that one should use what he is building if he wants to make something useful. I think that taking an active part in the blogging community would be the best way to experience the genuine needs of an RSS reader user.

So, let‚Äôs see what happens.
